author: Madeleine van Niekerk
title: JSE ends firmer in line with stronger global markets | Markets
text:
Picture: MICHAEL ETTERSHANK Related articles Gold dips as dollar steadies ahead of ECB meeting Oil down on crude build Bonds follow rand weaker in wake of local policy statement THE JSE closed higher on Wednesday, taking its cue from stronger global markets.
Major European markets were firmer at the JSE’s close and the Dow Jones industrial average gained 0.21% in early trade.
At 5pm, the all share ended 0.22% higher at 52,997 points with the blue-chip top 40 index up 0.39%.
Industrials led the upside on the bourse, adding 0.41%, while platinum and gold miners shed 3.78% and 3.34% respectively. Resources retreated 0.59%.
Barclays Research analysts said in a global note that markets would watch President Xi Jinping’s four-day visit to London this week, and China’s 13th Five-Year Plan at the plenary session on October 26-29.
Despite some recent policy "hiccups", Barclays believed the Chinese government remained committed to further reforms and the opening up of the economy.
China had also furthered the internationalisation agenda of its currency, the yuan, with the Peoples’ Bank of China (PBoC) "successfully" issuing its first offshore yuan bond in London, the analysts said.
The 5bn yuan 1-year bill attracted bids of more than 30bn yuan, they said.
Stock markets have been volatile since fears emerged over global growth after China weakened its currency in August.
Data released on Monday showed the Chinese economy grew 6.9% in the third quarter. While the figure was better than expected, it marked the slowest rate of expansion since 2009.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average is up 6% this month, while the Stoxx Europe 600 has gained 4.5%. However, the two indices are down about 4% and 10% respectively from three months ago, respectively, Dow Jones Newswires reported.
Among individual shares on the JSE, Anglo American closed 2.92% lower at R124.46, while rival BHP Billiton gained 1.23% to R227.23.
Global diversified miner BHP Billiton announced on Wednesday it would maintain its 247-million tons 2016 production guidance after another rise in iron ore output‚ flat year-on-year coal output and a decline in copper production.
ArcelorMittal shed 5% to R9.50.
Platinum stock Lonmin‚ the world’s third-largest platinum producer‚ closed 4.81% higher at R6.10 after surging 22% in intraday trade, after announcing on Wednesday that it will raise $400m in a rights issue and put in place an amended debt facility for $370m before the end of the year.
Impala Platinum shed 5.10% to R42.65.
Rand hedges gave the market a boost with British American Tobacco up 1.92% to R793.32, Richemont gaining 1.88% to R112.80 and SABMiller adding 1.24% to R824.
